elements.content: We report the first example of linker modification for an N-donor Ag-based cationic material while maintaining and in some cases increasing the anion exchange capacity. Cationic silver­(I) pyrazine nitrate selectively traps harmful oxo-anions from water such as permanganate, perrhenate and a variety of α,ω-alkanedicarboxylates. We chose these anions as initial examples of exchange for potential water purification. The host–guest interaction between the cationic layers of π-stacked silver pyrazine polymers and the incoming/outgoing interlamellar anions allows for the exchange. The exchange capacity over 24 h reached 435 and 818 mg/g for permanganate and perrhenate, respectively, a record for a crystalline metal–organic material and over five times the exchange capacity compared to commercial resin. The material also undergoes organic exchange as an analog for pharmaceutical waste, some of which have a carboxylate functionality at the neutral pH range typical of natural water sources. Both the as-synthesized and exchanged materials are characterized by a variety of analytical techniques.

elements.content: Open-framework metal–organic polymers, derived from a combination of selected transition metal and bridging ligands, have attracted much attention owing to their various potential applications including electrocatalysis, magnetism, luminescence, gas storage, ion exchange, and heterogeneous catalysis. Coordination polymers (CPs) based on Ag­(I) cations are attracting a great deal of attention, in part because they are structurally versatile. The coordination sphere of the d metal, Ag­(I), is very flexible and can adopt coordination numbers two to six and various geometries from linear to trigonal, tetrahedral, trigonal pyramidal, and octahedral. The structural flexibility of these complexes is essential for the investigation of noncovalent host–guest interactions. Weak intermolecular forces significantly affect the geometry and topology of the Ag­(I) coordination polymers in the solid state and in turn the anion exchange.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Open-framework metal-organic polymers, derived from a combination of selected transition metal and bridging ligands, have attracted much attention owing to their various potential applications including electrocatalysis, magnetism, luminescence, gas storage, ion exchange, and heterogeneous catalysis. Coordination polymers (CPs) based on Ag(I) cations are attracting a great deal of attention, in part because they are structurally versatile. The coordination sphere of the d metal, Ag(I), is very flexible and can adopt coordination numbers two to six and various geometries from linear to trigonal, tetrahedral, trigonal pyramidal, and octahedral. The structural flexibility of these complexes is essential for the investigation of noncovalent host-guest interactions. Weak intermolecular forces significantly affect the geometry and topology of the Ag(I) coordination polymers in the solid state and in turn the anion exchange.

elements.content: There has been much recent interest in the study of linear 1-D silver coordination polymers involving bridging N-heterocyclic ligands. The simplest such ligand is pyrazine, which has two nitrogen donors in its six-ring. Using a 1:1 ratio with silver nitrate, silver­(I) pyrazine structures can be synthesized. The first silver pyrazine structures, [Ag­(NC4H4N)+] n and [Ag­(NC4H4N)2 +] n , were first reported in the 1960s and have since been the subject of various studies including measurements of stability constants, infrared spectroscopy, and mass spectroscopy. Both structures displayed a high melting point (250 °C), which led the authors to suggest polymeric structures because pyrazine can act as bidentate bridging group. In a 1966 report, the silver pyrazine crystals were inherently twinned and the structure consisted of kinked chains of the type [−Ag–NC4H4N−] n . Due to the lability of the Ag-donor atom bond, the process of coordination polymer formation is highly reversible. As a result, the Ag­(I) coordination polymers can readily be crystallized with various counter-anions, allowing investigation by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Anion exchange was not studied; our group is thus interested in developing new anion exchange chemistry using silver pyrazine CPs.

The first silver pyrazine structures, [Ag(NC4H4N)+] n  and [Ag(NC4H4N)2 +] n , were first reported in the 1960s and have since been the subject of various studies including measurements of stability constants, infrared spectroscopy, and mass spectroscopy. Both structures displayed a high melting point (250 °C), which led the authors to suggest polymeric structures because pyrazine can act as bidentate bridging group. In a 1966 report, the silver pyrazine crystals were inherently twinned and the structure consisted of kinked chains of the type [-Ag-NC4H4N-] n . Due to the lability of the Ag-donor atom bond, the process of coordination polymer formation is highly reversible. As a result, the Ag(I) coordination polymers can readily be crystallized with various counter-anions, allowing investigation by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Anion exchange was not studied; our group is thus interested in developing new anion exchange chemistry using silver pyrazine CPs.

elements.content: Many of the priority pollutants in wastewater listed by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) are in their oxo-anionic form, for example, pertechnetate (TcO4 –), chromate (CrO4 2–), and arsenate (AsO4 3–). These toxic, harmful anions are problematic in the vitrification of low activity radioactive waste, weakening the integrity of the waste glass by forming spinels. Another class of water-borne toxic anion pollutants are organic, generated through both industrial processes and personal use. The EPA classifies many of these pollutants as pharmaceutical and personal care products (PPCPs). Many pharmaceuticals are sold in their acid or chloride form and consequently form anions when dissolved in water. Pharmaceutical anions and their metabolites are a growing problem because of ineffective removal or chlorination to toxic derivatives in wastewater treatment facilities.

elements.content: Resins with cationic side groups and exchangeable counteranions are still considered the standard ion exchanger. Due to their organic polymer nature, these resins are of limited thermal and chemical stability. One alternative to possibly replace resins is layered double hydroxides (LDHs), an isostructural group of materials containing cationic brucite type layers that are charged balanced by interlayer anions with general formula [M2+ 1–x M3+ x (OH)2]­[A n– x/n ]·xH2O where M2+ and M3+ are a range of metals, A n– is the intercalated anion, and x is ratio of M3+/(M2+ + M3+). LDHs generally suffer, however, from low selectivity and reintercalation of common anions such as carbonate or sulfate due to the memory effect.

LDHs generally suffer, however, from low selectivity and reintercalation of common anions such as carbonate or sulfate due to the memory effect.

elements.content: Owing to the structural diversity and weak host–guest interaction, cationic coordination polymers are gaining considerable attention for anion exchange. Silver-based CPs in particular have been previously studied for their ability to selectively trap anions via a crystal-to-crystal transition. We reported silver­(I) with 4,4-bipyridine polymers and ethanedisulfonate [EDS, –O3S­(CH2)2SO3 –] as a charge balance anion. We also reported oxo-anion pollutants exchange materials such as [Cu4(OH)6 2+]­[EDS2–]·2H2O and [M­(H2O)n(4,4′-bipyridine)2 2+]­[EDS2–] [M = Cu­(I), Ag­(I), Co­(II), or Zn­(II)]. We subsequently described silver-4,4′-bipyridine nitrate (SBN) and acetate (SBA) materials. Both circumvent the need for EDS anions and have even higher capacity, rate, selectivity, and reversibility for the trapping of perchlorate from water. Wang and co-workers recently reported a variety of cationic extended materials, denoted as SCU-n (Soochow University, structure No. n) with outstanding performance for TcO4 –/ReO4 – removal. These authors also recently reported organic polymers with similar properties. There have also been significant advances with selective crystallization approaches for anion removal and very recently Zr6O8-based cationic MOFs, though the latter require ligands with multiple step syntheses and have limited selectivity.

elements.content: In this study, a variety of anionic pollutants including permanganate, perrhenate (as an analog for pertechnetate) ,and α,ω-alkanedicarboxylates (as analogs for anionic pharmaceutical pollutants) were exchanged into the cationic CP Ag-pyrazine nitrate. The weak interaction between the interlamellar nitrates and the cationic silver pyrazine layers likely allows for the high capacity exchange.

The weak interaction between the interlamellar nitrates and the cationic silver pyrazine layers likely allows for the high capacity exchange.

For the exchange studies, the following were used as-purchased: potassium chromate (K2CrO4, Fischer Scientific), potassium permanganate (KMnO4, Acros Organics), sodium tetrafluoroborate (NaBF4, Acros Organics), potassium chloride (KCl, Fischer Scientific), potassium bromide (KBr, Acros Organics), potassium iodide (KI, Spectrum Chemical), sodium perrhenate (NaReO4, Alfa Aesar), disodium malonate ([−O2C–CH2–CO2 –]­Na2, TCI America), disodium succinate ([−O2C–(CH2)2–CO2 –]­Na2, TCI America), disodium glutarate ([−O2C–(CH2)–CO2 –]­Na2, TCI America), disodium adipate ([−O2C–(CH2)–CO2 –]­Na2, TCI America), disodium sebacate ([−O2C–(CH2)8–CO2 –]­Na2, TCI America), ascorbic acid (C6H8O6, Fischer Scientific), salicylic acid [HOC6H4(CO2H), Fischer Scientific], terephthalic acid [C8H4(CO2H)2, TCI America], 2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid [C10H6(COOH)2, TCI America], and Purolite A530E (Purolite).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Reagents

Silver nitrate (AgNO3, Alfa Aesar, 99%) and pyrazine (NC4H4N, Acros Organics, 99%) were used as-received for the synthesis. For the exchange studies, the following were used as-purchased: potassium chromate (K2CrO4, Fischer Scientific), potassium permanganate (KMnO4, Acros Organics), sodium tetrafluoroborate (NaBF4, Acros Organics), potassium chloride (KCl, Fischer Scientific), potassium bromide (KBr, Acros Organics), potassium iodide (KI, Spectrum Chemical), sodium perrhenate (NaReO4, Alfa Aesar), disodium malonate ([-O2C-CH2-CO2 -]Na2, TCI America), disodium succinate ([-O2C-(CH2)2-CO2 -]Na2, TCI America), disodium glutarate ([-O2C-(CH2)-CO2 -]Na2, TCI America), disodium adipate ([-O2C-(CH2)-CO2 -]Na2, TCI America), disodium sebacate ([-O2C-(CH2)8-CO2 -]Na2, TCI America), ascorbic acid (C6H8O6, Fischer Scientific), salicylic acid [HOC6H4(CO2H), Fischer Scientific], terephthalic acid [C8H4(CO2H)2, TCI America], 2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid [C10H6(COOH)2, TCI America], and Purolite A530E (Purolite).

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were obtained on a Rigaku Americas Miniflex Plus powder diffractometer, scanning from 2° to 40° (2θ) at a rate of 3°·min–1 with a 0.02° step size under Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) data were acquired on a PerkinElmer Optima 4300DV, run in radial mode using yttrium as an internal standard. A standard curve for silver­(I) was prepared to quantify the amount of free silver in the samples. Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy data was collected on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a TA Instruments Q500 TGA, heating from 25 to 600 °C with a gradient of 10 °C/min and nitrogen flow. In situ variable temperature PXRD (VT-PXRD) was performed on a Rigaku SmartLab X-ray Diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.57418 Å) from 2° to 70° (2θ) at a scan rate of 2°/min and 0.02° step size. The samples were heated at a rate of 10 °C/min and held at the set temperature for 5 min before scanning. SEM images were collected with a FEI Quanta 3D Dualbeam microscope.
elements.clean_text:
Instrumental Details

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were obtained on a Rigaku Americas Miniflex Plus powder diffractometer, scanning from 2° to 40° (2θ) at a rate of 3°⋅min-1 with a 0.02° step size under Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) data were acquired on a PerkinElmer Optima 4300DV, run in radial mode using yttrium as an internal standard. A standard curve for silver(I) was prepared to quantify the amount of free silver in the samples. Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy data was collected on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a TA Instruments Q500 TGA, heating from 25 to 600 °C with a gradient of 10 °C/min and nitrogen flow. In situ variable temperature PXRD (VT-PXRD) was performed on a Rigaku SmartLab X-ray Diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.57418 Å) from 2° to 70° (2θ) at a scan rate of 2°/min and 0.02° step size. The samples were heated at a rate of 10 °C/min and held at the set temperature for 5 min before scanning. SEM images were collected with a FEI Quanta 3D Dualbeam microscope.

elements.content: Silver nitrate and pyrazine (1:1 molar ratio) were added together in 10 mL of Millipore water, and the mixture was kept at 70 °C for 1 h. The reaction mixture was then cooled in an ice bath and rinsed with cold Millipore water and acetone. The filtration gave rise to white needle-like small crystals (yield: 65.8% based on AgNO3). Larger crystals were grown hydrothermally at 150 °C for 24 h. Direct synthesis of silver malonate was performed by mixing silver nitrate and sodium malonate (1:1 molar ratio) together in 10 mL of Millipore water, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The product was filtered and rinsed with Millipore water and acetone (yield: 63.4% based on AgNO3).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Silver nitrate and pyrazine (1:1 molar ratio) were added together in 10 mL of Millipore water, and the mixture was kept at 70 °C for 1 h. The reaction mixture was then cooled in an ice bath and rinsed with cold Millipore water and acetone. The filtration gave rise to white needle-like small crystals (yield: 65.8% based on AgNO3). Larger crystals were grown hydrothermally at 150 °C for 24 h. Direct synthesis of silver malonate was performed by mixing silver nitrate and sodium malonate (1:1 molar ratio) together in 10 mL of Millipore water, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The product was filtered and rinsed with Millipore water and acetone (yield: 63.4% based on AgNO3).

elements.content: The exchange reactions were performed by placing [Ag­(pyrazine)+]­[NO3 –] (0.2 mmol) and the anion of interest (0.2 mmol) in 10 mL of Millipore water. The resulting systems were kept under 300–400 rpm magnetic stirring rate at room temperature 25 °C for 24 h. Equimolar quantities were used for all anion exchanges but modified if necessary according to the charge of the incoming anion. The selectivity tests were performed by introducing the material into a sealed beaker containing 10 mL Millipore water and the anion mixture of interest (0.2 mmol for each). The reaction was stirred for 24 h under ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Anion Exchange

The exchange reactions were performed by placing [Ag(pyrazine)+][NO3 -] (0.2 mmol) and the anion of interest (0.2 mmol) in 10 mL of Millipore water. The resulting systems were kept under 300-400 rpm magnetic stirring rate at room temperature 25 °C for 24 h. Equimolar quantities were used for all anion exchanges but modified if necessary according to the charge of the incoming anion. The selectivity tests were performed by introducing the material into a sealed beaker containing 10 mL Millipore water and the anion mixture of interest (0.2 mmol for each). The reaction was stirred for 24 h under ambient conditions.

elements.content:
To study the leaching of silver ion of exchanged product [Ag­(pyrazine)+]­[ReO4 –], the sample was placed in water under dark, static conditions for 24 h and the solution was analyzed by ICP-OES.

Results and Discussion

The Ag­(I) pyrazine nitrate (SPN) structure () was synthesized using a slight modification of the literature method. The crystals were formed within 1 h under low heat, as evidenced by the match of the experimental PXRD pattern to the theoretical pattern simulated from single crystal data (). The single crystal data and structure refinement indicate a much better structure solution (4.84%) that the previous publication (9.10%) ().
elements.clean_text:
Silver Leaching

To study the leaching of silver ion of exchanged product [Ag(pyrazine)+][ReO4 -], the sample was placed in water under dark, static conditions for 24 h and the solution was analyzed by ICP-OES.

Results and Discussion

The Ag(I) pyrazine nitrate (SPN) structure () was synthesized using a slight modification of the literature method. The crystals were formed within 1 h under low heat, as evidenced by the match of the experimental PXRD pattern to the theoretical pattern simulated from single crystal data (). The single crystal data and structure refinement indicate a much better structure solution (4.84%) that the previous publication (9.10%) ().

elements.content: SPN crystallizes as colorless needle crystals (). The crystals are in the P 1 space group of the triclinic system. Single crystal XRD revealed that the structure contains one-dimensional silver­(I) pyrazine chains, π-stacked [3.483(2) to 3.975(4) Å] into layers with charge-balancing nitrate anions between the layers (). The chains are slightly kinked with Ag–N distance ranging from 2.211(7) to 2.229(7) Å (). Within the polymeric chain, the N–Ag–N is significantly bent at an angle of 157.4(2)°, likely due to the presence of weakly coordinating oxygen atoms of nearby nitrate anions. The bond length between Ag­(I) and the oxygen from nitrate was 2.558(6) Å, creating weak covalent Ag–O bonds that play a crucial role in the anion exchangeability (vide infra).

elements.content: The thermal behavior of SPN was investigated by in situ variable temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), both under a nitrogen flow (). At 145 °C, an additional unknown crystalline phase appeared [first peak at ∼12° (2θ)]. Both the original phase and this new phase are gone by 225 °C, replaced by peaks at ∼19°, 21°, 24°, and 29° (2θ, peaks indicated with asterisks in ) and correspond to silver nitrate (ICDD PDF #00–043–0649). The TGA trace showed only a single weight loss at ∼175 °C and is likely due to the partial loss of pyrazine (calculated: 20.8%, observed: 18.1%). At 400 °C, the VT-PXRD shows a mixed phase of silver nitrate, silver oxide (ICDD PDF #03–065–3289, peaks indicated by number signs), and silver metal (ICDD PDF #01–071–5025, peaks indicated by solid diamond).

elements.content: All of the anion exchange studies of [Ag­(pyrazine)+]­[NO3 –] were performed in aqueous conditions and pH 7. The first exchange investigated was organic, using various α,ω-alkanedicarboxylate anions. An equimolar ratio of malonate, succinate, glutarate, adipate, or sebacate to the CP material was tested in aqueous solution (). The principal peak of the as-synthesized nitrate-containing material is at 12.5° (2θ) (a), corresponding to a basal spacing of 7.1 Å (). On the basis of the relative carbon chain length and size of carbonate end groups [−O2C­(CH2) n CO2 –], it was expected that succinate (n = 2), glutarate (n = 3), adipate (n = 4), and sebacate (n = 8) would shift the principal (200) peak to lower 2θ values as the interlayer distance increases.

The principal peak of the as-synthesized nitrate-containing material is at 12.5° (2θ) (a), corresponding to a basal spacing of 7.1 Å (). On the basis of the relative carbon chain length and size of carbonate end groups [-O2C(CH2) n CO2 -], it was expected that succinate (n = 2), glutarate (n = 3), adipate (n = 4), and sebacate (n = 8) would shift the principal (200) peak to lower 2θ values as the interlayer distance increases.

elements.content: As the number of carbons of the dicarboxylate anion increased, the 2θ value of the 100% peak decreased according to Bragg’s law (). Attempts to reverse the exchange have been unsuccessful to date, implying that the organic-intercalated materials are of higher stability. The [Ag­(pyrazine)+]­[−O2C­(CH2) n CO2 –] materials are thermally stable up to 300 °C (), which further supports the irreversibility. The appearance of carboxylate peaks in the FTIR spectra also confirms that organic uptake has taken place (). The C=O and C–O stretches of carboxylate bands were found at 1570 and 1300 cm–1, respectively.

elements.content: The selectivity among the α,ω-alkanedicarboxylates was also tested to see if there is a preference between them. The exchange started out with a mixture of even (C2, C4, and C8) or odd (C1, C3, and C8) carbon chain length dicarboxylates (). In all tests, sebacate [−O2C­(CH2)8CO2 –] was the only phase observed, likely due to its greater amphiphilicity and thus stability of the n = 8 phase via van der Waals close-packing.

elements.content: In addition to α,ω-alkanedicarboxylates, the material displays high capacity inorganic anion exchange for water-borne metal oxo-anion pollutants. Permanganate, perrhenate, and tetrafluoroborate were studied as initial examples. The latter was chosen as a comparative tetrahedral anion whereas permanganate and perrhenate were selected as group 7 surrogates for pertechnetate, which is a problematic radioactive pollutant during the vitrification of nuclear waste. An equimolar amount of permanganate and as-synthesized SPN were introduced into aqueous solution under mild stirring. As monitored by UV–vis spectroscopy, the permanganate concentration rapidly decreased by 32% to 57% with reaction intervals of 0.5 to 3 h, respectively (). The uptake of permanganate was confirmed by PXRD () and was 92% after 24 h with an adsorption capacity of 435 mg/g (0.91 mol/mol). This uptake performance is better than SLUG-21 (292 mg/g) and Ag­[4,4′-bis­(1,2,4-triazole)]­PF6·0.5CH3CN (342 mg/g).

To understand the change in morphology of SPN during anion exchange with perrhenate, in situ optical microscopy was performed to monitor the transformation between the two crystalline phases (). As-synthesized SPN crystals were immersed in an aqueous solution of sodium perrhenate under ambient conditions, yielding the highly crystalline phase [Ag­(pyrazine)+]­[ReO4 –]. The formation of [Ag­(pyrazine)+]­[ReO4 –] was observed on the surface of the SPN crystals after 40 min. The competitive crystallization allows [Ag­(pyrazine)+]­[ReO4 –] to gradually grow at the expense of the original SPN crystal to form the distinct new phase and crystal morphology after 60 min. Unlike solid-state equilibrium-driven anion exchange process for LDHs, this crystal-to-crystal transition process indicates that our material undergoes a solvent-mediated recrystallization mechanism typical of this type of material, including SBN.

The formation of [Ag(pyrazine)+][ReO4 -] was observed on the surface of the SPN crystals after 40 min. The competitive crystallization allows [Ag(pyrazine)+][ReO4 -] to gradually grow at the expense of the original SPN crystal to form the distinct new phase and crystal morphology after 60 min. Unlike solid-state equilibrium-driven anion exchange process for LDHs, this crystal-to-crystal transition process indicates that our material undergoes a solvent-mediated recrystallization mechanism typical of this type of material, including SBN.

elements.content: The adsorption capacity of SPN is 818 mg ReO4 –/g of material, higher than that of SBN (786 mg/g), NDTB (720 mg/g), SCU-COF-1 (702.4 mg/g), SLUG-21 (602 mg/g), SCU-8 (540 mg/g), SCU-100 (541 mg/g), SCU-102 (291 mg/g), SCU-101 (217 mg/g), and UiO-66-NH3 + (159 mg/g). The rate of uptake is slower than that of SBN, SCU-8, SCU-100, SCU-101, and SCU-COF-1 nor did it reach as high a capacity as the recently reported organic polymer, SCU-CPN-1 (999 mg/g). Our material is extremely easy to synthesize using water, commerically available reagents, and ambient conditions. The higher specific uptake of SPN versus the other CP/MOF type materials is likely due to the shorter and thus lighter organic linker, coupled with a higher cationic charge density and thus anion density. PXRD before and after anion exchange confirmed that SPN retains its crystalline layered character after intercalation, with the d-spacing slightly increasing from 7.0 to 7.4 Å due to the larger anion (). The exchange for both permanganate and perrhenate were irreversible after all attempts. Reusability is, in fact, undesirable for a highly problematic pollutant such as the radionuclide pertechnetate.

elements.content:
Since BF4 –, MnO4 –, and ReO4 – all have tetrahedral geometry, we were interested in the selectivity. According to PXRD data, perrhenate outperformed the other anions ().

Given the high adsorption capacity of [Ag­(pyrazine)+]­[ReO4 –], we also performed the competition study with chloride (Cl–) which is commonly present in water (). The selectivity of SPN for perrhenate over chloride was demonstrated by performing two lower chloride concentration tests containing 100 and 200 ppm, as evidenced by PXRD (b,c). In both tests it was observed that the chloride did not interfere with the uptake of perrhenate. When SPN is exposed to an equimolar ratio of ReO4 – and Cl–, the resulting mixture gave rise to pure-phase AgCl (d).

elements.content: We attempted to prepare crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction in order to have a deeper understanding of the specific binding. Among them, only [Ag­(pyrazine)+]­[ReO4 –] successfully yielded colorless needle-type crystals, matching the theoretical pattern based on the crystal data reported by Maggard et al. The ReO4 – tetrahedra, which reside in the space between the silver pyrazine layers, are separated from each other by 4.61 Å (O1–O1’). Each ReO4 – tetrahedron bonds via three O vertices to three different Ag+ ions in the layer [Ag–O distance 2.603(3) to 2.686(5) Å], creating stronger silver to oxygen bonds than BF4 – and MnO4 – anions (). Indeed, Wang et al. reported density functional theory (DFT) analysis for the bonding of a similar silver­(I) polymer, [Ag­(4,4′-bipyridine)+]­[ReO4 –], where ReO4 – has a stronger electrostatic interaction with the polymers that creates a better match of coordinating environment compared to other anions such as BF4 – and MnO4 –.

Each ReO4 - tetrahedron bonds via three O vertices to three different Ag+ ions in the layer [Ag-O distance 2.603(3) to 2.686(5) Å], creating stronger silver to oxygen bonds than BF4 - and MnO4 - anions (). elements.content: A silver leaching measurement was carried out to verify the stability of the SPN material and to confirm the heterogeneous nature of the CP. The material was placed in solution, and the latter was analyzed after 24 h using ICP-OES in order to measure the leached silver. The concentration of the leached silver in the solution was found to be less than 2% for all the samples (). This may be due to the strong interaction of silver with nitrogen from pyrazine groups which prevents the leaching of silver from the polymer matrix.

Attempts to intercalate other aromatic dicarboxylates such as salicylic acid, p-terephthalate, and 2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylate were not successful, likely due to the limited aqueous solubility of these analytes at neutral pH. Other reports of the intercalation of terephthalate derivatives into cationic materials occurred in basic aqueous solutions. PXRD data revealed that the exchange products turned out to be identical to the directly synthesized silver dicarboxylates (), confirming that pyrazine in this case had been lost upon the exchange attempt.

elements.content: The ability to modify the N-donor linker for these Ag-based cationic CP materials may allow tuning of the anion propensity for water purification and pollution abatement. The cationic material silver­(I) pyrazine shows the highest group 7 oxo-anion uptake (435 and 818 mg/g for permanganate and perrhenate, respectively) to date for a metal–organic extended structure, making it potentially useful to trap pertechnetate. The capacity and kinetics far outperform those of the anion exchange resin Purolite 530E. Unlike some of the recently reported cationic MOFs, all of the synthesis and exchange occur aqueously with commercially available reagents. With the formation of a new crystal structure driving the reaction, the anions become incorporated into a structure. The reuse of the material would, in fact, be undesirable for a highly problematic radionuclide. The material also displays uptake toward organic water-borne pollutants through a series of α,ω-alkanedicarboxylates.

The material also displays uptake toward organic water-borne pollutants through a series of α,ω-alkanedicarboxylates.

The manuscript was written through contributions of all authors. All authors have given approval to the final version of the manuscript.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

cln_elements.content: Silver nitrate and pyrazine (1:1 molar ratio) were added together in 10 mL of Millipore water, and the mixture was kept at 70 °C for 1 h. The reaction mixture was then cooled in an ice bath and rinsed with cold Millipore water and acetone. The filtration gave rise to white needle-like small crystals (yield: 65.8% based on AgNO3). Larger crystals were grown hydrothermally at 150 °C for 24 h. Direct synthesis of silver malonate was performed by mixing silver nitrate and sodium malonate (1:1 molar ratio) together in 10 mL of Millipore water, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The product was filtered and rinsed with Millipore water and acetone (yield: 63.4% based on AgNO3).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Silver nitrate and pyrazine (1:1 molar ratio) were added together in 10 mL of Millipore water, and the mixture was kept at 70 °C for 1 h. The reaction mixture was then cooled in an ice bath and rinsed with cold Millipore water and acetone. The filtration gave rise to white needle-like small crystals (yield: 65.8% based on AgNO3). Larger crystals were grown hydrothermally at 150 °C for 24 h. Direct synthesis of silver malonate was performed by mixing silver nitrate and sodium malonate (1:1 molar ratio) together in 10 mL of Millipore water, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The product was filtered and rinsed with Millipore water and acetone (yield: 63.4% based on AgNO3).
